channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: South Korean Leader Warns of Possible ‘Provocations’ From North
item.description: Citing uncertainty about the North Korean regime following a dramatic purge, President Park Geun-hye ordered the military and police to step up their vigilance.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Koreans left flowers at the base of statues of the late leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang, Monday, the eve of the second anniversary of the death of Kim Jong-il.

item.title: A New Feeling for Egypt’s Bare-Knuckled Police: Fear
item.description: More than 150 Egyptian police officers have been killed since mid-August alone, and the attacks have affected morale on the force.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian police officers standing guard near a police academy in a Cairo suburb last month.

item.title: African Refugees Protest Detainment in Israel
item.description: About 200 asylum seekers from Sudan and Eritrea being held in a facility in the desert spent two days making their way to Jerusalem, where they protested their treatment by the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Europe Warns of Human Risk From Insecticides
item.description: A class of pesticides already banned in Europe to protect bees might also harm people, health officials concluded.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM

item.title: Outrage in India Over Female Diplomat’s Arrest in New York
item.description: Assertions that the official, accused of underpaying a housekeeper, was strip searched, and retaliation against the American Embassy.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Russia Offers Ukraine a Financial Lifeline
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would provide $15 billion in loans and a sharp discount on natural gas prices, a bold move in his recent diplomatic battle with the West.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin during a signing ceremony Tuesday in Moscow.

item.title: British Surgeon Reportedly Dies in Syrian Jail
item.description: The family of Dr. Abbas Khan had been expecting his release this week but was informed he had died.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Britain Opens Door to More Shale Gas Drilling
item.description: The government said it planned to award more drilling permits next year, despite persistent opposition from environmental groups.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Bridging the Mideast Divide With Comedy
item.description: The film "Peace After Marriage," a Turkish-French-American production that has picked up several festival awards, is a farcical tale on the Israeli-Palestinian bedroom barrier.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Michael Nagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ghazi Albuliwi, the writer-director-star of “Peace After Marriage,” the farcical tale of a Palestinian-American who marries an Israeli desperate for a green card.

item.title: The Lede: Egyptians Mock Ads Promoting New Constitution With Typos and Stock Images
item.description: A campaign to win support for Egypt’s new constitution got off to a rocky start when bloggers noticed that a banner promoting the document misspelled the word for “Egyptians” in Arabic and used stock images of foreigners.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 6 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Copter Crash in Afghanistan
item.description: There is believed to be at least one survivor after a helicopter went down in a rugged area of southern Afghanistan. Afghan officials cited possible mechanical trouble.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and THOM SHANKER

item.title: Aid Challenge in Syria Mounts for U.N. Official
item.description: Some rights advocates say Valerie Amos, the United Nations relief coordinator, has been too patient with the Syrian government in pushing for access to areas in need.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Valerie Amos, the top United Nations relief official. Ms. Amos is under pressure to be tougher with the Syrian authorities.

item.title: Snowden Offers to Help Brazil With N.S.A. Inquiry
item.description: The former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, who had requested asylum from Brazil months ago, made the offer in a letter published in a Brazilian newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Forced Labor Lives On in Uzbekistan’s Cotton Fields
item.description: Every autumn, the government drafts about a million people — including doctors, teachers and other professionals — to pick cotton, providing free labor for the world’s fifth-largest cotton exporter.
item.dc:creator: By MANSUR MIROVALEV and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: U.S. Forging Closer Military Ties With Philippines
item.description: Americans officials want to rotate more military forces through the country, concerned about mounting pressure from China on its neighbors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Boycott by Academic Group Is a Symbolic Sting to Israel
item.description: An association of American professors with almost 5,000 members has become the largest academic group in the country to support a push to isolate Israel over its treatment of Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli Arab students at the Technion, an Israeli university in Haifa. Critics of the boycott effort say it hurts academic freedom.

item.title: Japan Moves to Strengthen Military Amid Rivalry With China
item.description: The plan, described as “proactive pacifism,” calls for acquiring airborne drones and amphibious assault vehicles, and it reverses a decade of military spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 17
item.description: A foggy day in Amritsar, Punjab.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A Sikh man on a foggy day at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, Punjab.

item.title: India Ink: Calls Grow Louder for Human Rights Chairman to Resign After Harassment Complaint
item.description: Lawmakers on Tuesday demanded Asok Kumar Ganguly, a retired Supreme Court justice, step down from a West Bengal commission after he was accused of harassing a law intern.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Russia Buys $15 Billion of Ukrainian Government Bonds
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says Moscow has agreed to sharply cut the price for its natural gas supplies to Ukraine and will buy $15 billion worth of Ukrainian government bonds.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, with the Ukrainian President Viktor F. Yanukovich on Tuesday during a signing ceremony for the agreement at the Kremlin in Moscow.

item.title: German Parliament Elects Merkel to Third Term
item.description: The vote came nearly three months after Ms. Merkel fell short of winning a clear majority in the general election, forcing her to form a “grand coalition.”
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Car Bomb Targets Hezbollah Post in Lebanon
item.description: The attack underscores the heightened political and sectarian tensions in Lebanon caused by Hezbollah’s involvement in the conflict in Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Response to Thomas L. Friedman’s ‘Letter’ to President Xi
item.description: Global Times, a newspaper belonging to the flagship People’s Daily, has responded with apparent frankness to a column by Thomas L. Friedman, who warned against expelling Western journalists for their reporting on China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Global Times said that Thomas L. Friedman was out of touch with China's security concerns.

item.title: British Panel Narrows Options for Expanding Airport Capacity
item.description: While its shortlist included proposals for Heathrow and Gatwick, the panel did not completely rule out the idea of a new airport.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Lens Blog: Illuminating a Central African Crisis, Photo by Photo
item.description: While the world was watching the funeral of Nelson Mandela, Jerome Delay made it his mission to remain in the violence-wracked Central African Republic, hoping to shed light on the crisis there.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Mobs of Christians grabbed a boy with a knife during scuffles near the airport in Bangui. Dec. 9.
